messages.text: Alright, I tagged 1.1.13. I'd say from now on we don't merge anything, unless it fixes a major regression. So we'll put a hold on minor bug fixes as well, until we have shipped 1.1 to the release channel. I would say that if we don't see any major problems on the insider channel, I push 1.1.13 out to the release channel Thu morning pacific time.

elements.text: Alright, I tagged 1.1.13. I'd say from now on we don't merge anything, unless it fixes a major regression. messages.text: :slightly_smiling_face:

Alright, let's go with #1898 then. I still think debouncing is better than cancelling when we don't care about the result (because what we have implemented as "cancelling" doesn't actually cancel anything, it just ignores the result).

elements.text: Alright, let's go with #1898 then. I still think debouncing is better than cancelling when we don't care about the result (because what we have implemented as "cancelling" doesn't actually cancel anything, it just ignores the result).

messages.text: I read a bit more, and I think what we really want is the `RateLimiter` in <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/22318#issuecomment-316497469>, in combination with the cancellation token story. That is essentially the combination of debouncing _and_ cancellation.

, in combination with the cancellation token story. That is essentially the combination of debouncing
and

messages.text: Hi <@U6BNE7LTZ> I saw that you use a file called `documenter-vscode.scss` to manage the style of the document panel. For the plot panel, I’m trying to create a similar scss called “plotter.scss”. However, it seems that I could not compile the scss because it actually imports something. Could you inform me of a way of compiling it?

elements.text: Hi
I saw that you use a file called
documenter-vscode.scss

to manage the style of the document panel. For the plot panel, I’m trying to create a similar scss called “plotter.scss”. However, it seems that I could not compile the scss because it actually imports something. Could you inform me of a way of compiling it?

messages.text: Yes. I’m using that currently, but thanks for the advice! The reason for an external JavaScript file is that it will make the program more readable and editable (and plot.ts uses many external js files already). I’ll make them inline if the JavaScript and/or SCSS is less than 100 lines after the whole program is written to balance the tradeoff.
